All that said, the weakness of the legal cases made thus far, the associated lack of evidence of voter fraud, the margin of the Biden electoral victory and Supreme Court institutional equities make the chance remain quite low.

In order for the Supreme Court to hear a case, it would have to be heard at the state level first. Since the state keeps dismissing the case, the Supreme Court cannot hear it.  Assuming the case is capable of being heard by the U.S. Supreme Court, the first step, most of the time, is to file a lawsuit in your local state or federal court. The trial judge would hear evidence and consider legal arguments from each side before making a decision. If the judge decides all or part of the case against you, you can then appeal the case to a higher court. When you have appealed as far as possible, you can consider appealing to the U.S. Supreme Court. (https://www.findlaw.com/litigation/legal-system/how-does-the-u-s-supreme-court-decide-whether-to-hear-a-case.html) Here is the schedule for the court in December. https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/hearinglists/Hearinglist-December2020.pdf Also, even Trump doubts the Supreme Court will hear his voter fraud claim https://www.ft.com/content/943687e7-e3e9-482c-9d38-98ba511a82cc

The official government website states that SCOTUS hears about 70-80 cases per year, and those are most often on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays, with two arguments per day. Therefore, there would be, under such a base rate, only 9 days / 18 cases as available opportunities remaining until 14 December. Another base rate assessment shows that of the available 70-80 cases heard per year (from October to April) ~12% of available opportunities are available, reinforcing the ~9-10 days / 18-20 case availability remaining. Importantly, while this is a very timely topic that could (and should) be prioritized if necessary, the collection of data required for making an oral argument is simply not going to be available in time (given the ongoing Senate race in Georgia as an example). Because that state would be necessary for a change in the election outcome, and the outcome of the state is still in progress, this becomes all the more unlikely. One of my 11th great-grandfathers was a Mayflower Passenger. William Bradford. "In 1620, a group of pilgrims left England seeking religious freedom. Upon their arrival in the New World, they created the Mayflower Compact, which established self-governance for the colony and helped shape the nation that eventually became the United States of America. The best information on William Bradford is found in his own writings, particularly in his history of the Plymouth Colony (there is a fascinating story of how this manuscript was found after having been lost for many years). William Bradford as a young man from Yorkshire, England became affiliated with the Separatists, who had gone beyond the Puritan thinking and wanted to be completely separate from the official Church of England. He joined a congregation at Scrooby, Nottinghamshire, led by Richard Clyfton and John Robinson. William Brewster, who was master of the post station at Scrooby, joined this church and later became its Ruling Elder, while William Bradford also joined the church and became a life-long follower and friend to Elder Brewster. After being persecuted in England, the congregation decided in 1607 to move to Holland - living for one year in Amsterdam and then moving to Leiden. Many of the congregation worked in some fashion in the clothing trade to support themselves, with William Bradford employed as a fustian maker (rough sturdy cloth made of cotton and flax).
Concerned about economic problems as not being citizens of Leiden and about temptations facing their children, these Separatists in Leiden learned about North America from the writings of Captain John Smith who was at the Jamestown, VA settlement. They turned down an offer from Captain Smith to captain a ship to take them to North America and chose for their captain an English soldier living in Holland named Myles Standish. Those Separatists in Leiden who traveled to England to cross the ocean were joined by other Separatists and by some people called "Strangers" by Bradford (not members of their faith, but with whom they had to ravel in order to get support for their venture). The first group left England on 23 Aug 1620 in two ships, but the Speedwell sprung a leak and had to return to England while the Mayflower continued on alone. Their intended destination in "Northern Virginia' was to have been about where Manhattan is located today, but they sailed further north - outside the Virginia limits. After first anchoring at the Provincetown harbor on Cape Cod, they explored the Plymouth harbor and decided to settle there. While still anchored in the Provincetown harbor, all free adults signed the Mayflower Compact, which stated essentially that the individual would subject himself to majority rule. Dorothy (May) Bradford, first wife of William Bradford, died 7 Dec 1620 by drowning at Provincetown while Bradford was away exploring the Plymouth area. After the death of the first governor, John Carver, in 1621, William Bradford was chosen to succeed him. He continued to be elected to this position for the years 1621-33, 1635, 1637, 1639-43, and 1645-56. At his death, he reportedly was the richest man in the colony. He left a library containing 275 books and is said to have had a knowledge of several languages, including Hebrew. His noncupative Will was dated 9 May 1657 and proved 3 Jun 1657."  Genealogical records are available to all with a little digging. It is quite amazing how far one can go back. In my case, I have connected to verified lines that go back over a thousand years and am directly related to people I've read about in history books my whole life (even Vlad the impaler ((and a whole plethora of heros and villains))).

Trump is going to want to take the issue out of the state courts and get it to the US Supreme Court where there are at least some conservative judges. While the Supreme Court denied the initial emergency request to rule on the constitutionality of the Pennsylvania issue, the court said that while they didn't have time to rule on the issue before the election, they left it open to rule on it later if necessary. So I don't think the US Supreme Court is necessarily trying to avoid hearing these cases.  As a bit of a sidebar, I think it's useful to look at what happens here in Oregon. We've had Democrat leadership for many decades. While the judge positions are supposedly nonpartisan and supposedly elected by the people, which in theory would make them not controlled by party leadership, in practice what happens is the judges routinely leave their posts early so that the governor can appoint a judge to fill the remainder of the term. Then at the next election that judge runs as an incumbent and often unopposed. So in practice all the judges are political appointees. The fact that the judges are willing to step down before the end of their term is good evidence that they are not acting as objective parties just interpreting the law, but they actually have a partisan motivation in exercising their office.

The CJ is very anxious to keep the Court out of this sandbox brawl.  He has said in the past that it is not the Court's role to instruct the states in how to apply their own statutes, and on that basis he can probably get his colleagues to refuse cert on anything based on state laws.
